uCl45P1St56-BW6oKO4BTg.text: As a student I used to go and scoff pizza here regularly. I recently went back here with my mum with empty stomachs on a very cold day. We were seated promptly but were forgotten about for a little while until we finally managed to get the waiters attention. My mum mentioned the lack of service and it was good from then on. We ordered a pizza from the specials menu and it was delicious and just how I remembered it. The pizza is in the traditional Italian thin base style and the menu has some interesting topping combo's without breaking the bank. One thing that this Pizza place really has going for it though, is the views of the Thames. We were there at sunset and it was absolutley beautiful. My tip for a date is to plan ahead and book a table by the window for sunset, lovely.

oT9HJDVTi2BippjJ-0S2eA.text: Restaurant owners: in case you don't have a fancy college education, I'll let you in on a little secret... the definition of gourmet does not mean disgruntled waiting staff and below average food. Canned pineapple, lettuce and those crappy tiny frozen prawns you get in prawn cocktail does not a 'Gourmet Salad' make! Also olive oil does not constitute a salad dressing in my book, it's just oil.

tK24653mLOWVdu6SimHTXg.text: Avoid this restaurant like the plague My girlfriend and i went here, and were the last people to leave, whilst we were walking out my girlfriend slipped on their either wet or very slippery floor, trying to stop herself from falling she knocked a few unfortunately placed bottles of wine over , nothing was broken but the manager, Mr Kasim Jashri , instead of asking if she was ok started shouting and screaming at her her that she could of broken themAn arguement insued and then a scuffle broke out in which my girlfriend was man handled and knocked to the floor injuring her elbow and hand.The management in this establishment are a poor excuse of human kind and behaved in an absolutley appaulling manner. I strongly advise everyone to stay away from this restaurant as the management have a total disregard for, and have no idea of how to treat or speak to their customers or have any respect for them.GO TO THE GOURMET PIZZA COMPANY AT YOUR PERIL!!!

7m-ANyMGTlhnY2j3pxHMZA.text: If you're looking for great pizza this is the place to go! I love this restaurant mainly due to its fantastic location on the South Bank and if you're lucky enough to get a window seat on the river then you couldn't ask for a better spot to enjoy food in London. There's a really pleasant village atmosphere to the area with a few boutique type shops and other restaurants and cafes. The menu is mainly pizza but they do offer other great Italian food but why bother when the pizzas are so amazing?! The staff aren't always the friendliest but this is understandable as I've never seen this place any less than full so they're busy working hard all day long. It's very romantic when coupled with a walk down the river after your meal in the evening through, what's recognised by many, as the cultural focal point of London. I most definitely recommend Gourmet Pizza!

v9ukc5CwcJf8rrOOuireyQ.text: I was lucky enough with my brother-in-law to get tickets for a TV show at London Studios and having arrived a little early we took a wander round the area. Our intention was to head into central London for food after the recording however we soon changed our mind as the aroma from the GPC hit us. So having been suitably entertained we arrived and queued for seats. As there were larger parties in front of us we were seated quickly in the 'Al fresco' area however as it was a summer eveing we had no complaints about our view over the Thames in to London. Our orders were quickly taken and dispatched to us and having had 2 courses and a drink we were out in 45 mins. The food was delicious and the best part was the cost £26!! Try getting that in central London.

0ZmIHwJOzSCIPbN_VXo2xQ.text: Came here on a date. Decided we were hungry and fancied a pizza snack. The location is very nice along the river. The setting kinda romantic. The pizza... not too bad. Had the Chicago pizza. Nothing like a real Chicago pizza so i'm not sure where they got the name for that pizza. The meat on it wasn't very nice as it tasted like  sloppy joe meat. But outside of the sweetened ground beef, it was nice.However, very difficult to cut into the thing when they only give you a butter knife. It was a big challenge for me and my date. Tho we did find it a funny.And the staff were very friendly. All and all, i would happily return.

Youp7dWeGi-s6dmV1wdM9g.text: Ah St Gabriel's Wharf. It's such a cool and quirky little place in the middle of Southbank. I loves its old style fishing village feel, ramshackled huts and a miniature beach at the front where you can take in the acrid Thames river breeze... Well nowhere's perfect!Quick lunch here to treat ourselves with a work friend. We went because she has a Taste card and could get half price. We got there and were told they no longer accept Taste cards. Well please update your information then! We stayed anyway, how can you not when you're under time pressure to eat lunch.Nice inside though, we grabbed a table in a conservatory-like annexe for optimum people watching (my favourite restaurant pasttime/ favourite pasttime in most situations!). A cheeky glass of wine each as a treat, we considered splitting a bottle but decided to be good and not drink overly during work hours. Frankly, I think a small round of applause for us is due if you're reading this!Healthy option to compensate for wine, we had salads. I had tuna nicoise, really fresh and good helping of all the ingredients. Too much parmesan though, the whole thing was a bit salty - it had anchovies as well and that is too much salt indeed! Nice portion though, I was full by the end. My friend has chicken and avocado, also looked good. Service was fine, nothing special but we got served quickly enough. The killer for me was price. For that quality salad and a glass of wine I would hope about £13-15. £17 is a touch much (casual rhyme for you there reader) for my liking. Good spot though, LOVE THE LOCATION

zpx5d9EY-V4tp_xaOXLejQ.text: The pizza was pretty good.  It wasn't the best I've ever had, but it was solid.  I would eat here again. They serve the pizza whole.  I wish they would have sliced it, so it would be easier to eat.  It was a bit challenging to try to cut the pizza with a butter knife.

photos.caption: Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom. Chicago pizza
Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom. Hot and spicy macho pizza

c5AZ38e0pHGYwL1k-bC4pQ.text: The bruschetta was to die for!  Also we loved the pizza--very good crust and flavorful toppings.  We loved the area and walked along the Thames which is right outside the restaurant after dinner.  We would certainly recommend it.

N5ugYtQ1Imngr9pTMc4Rjw.text: Am a big fan of this place - one of my favourite ever pizza places - and they do dough balls which makes me excessively happy. Gorgeous location too, right on southbank in Gabriel's wharf. Really good value for money too.

a_eIi4M-FYOggUhxbH64TQ.text: Wow. That was the smallest pizza size i have ever seen. Ordered a 4 cheese pizza. There was barely any cheese on it. It taste like just bread with a bit of tomato. And not that great actually. Unbelievable. The place look nice and it is in a nice location but don't get fooled by the name. Should be called broken pizza

iLvZGOqtnODjHNeW7rTbLw.text: I ordered a sausage pizza and it came with pepperoni. That might've been my mistake but I think the menu should've been clearer. The waiter seemed like he didn't want to serve us and gave us blank looks. The view was nice because it was river front. Don't expect your pizza to be pre-cut!

mBnrb0oIzzJxK4BBKkQD2w.text: Pretty uninspiring and average. Doughy pizzas but ok quality ingredients . Average taste from an electric oven. Awful tiramisu, avoid like the plague.

v2mdkRvQ52hn8fn3uLIFew.text: Some of the most mediocre pizza in London, served in one of the most uncomfortable dining rooms in London, by some of the most uninterested restaurant staff. Total tourist trap. You're much better off at a Pizza Express.

sn3aBUnf9AIIV9bCUzNKvA.text: This is one of my favourite south bank haunts. Unpretentious pizza, cheerful staff, speedy service (once you've ordered) and a brilliant range of toppings (Chinese duck, beetroot...) that make this place one of those nice finds for a Summer's evening when you want to watch the world and her wife roll by on the South Bank.Most seating has a a reasonable view out, and generally the place is reasonable for this bit of London.

iwWKTXyl4nQ8O-0Q47cq0w.text: I was not that impressed by the pizza place. The pizzas were ok but I did not like the overall service  it was slow and when the pizzas came they weren't even hot. Also I had to wait way too long for the restroom which was not acceptable.

QQnB6Lb90RF7q5NkqkXKow.text: This place is on the South bank, has pretty tasty pizza and does its chilli oil right! Real chilis in oil! The place is a bit cramped on the inside and drinks are a bit much, but outside is really a nice sunset sitting point.

PiaIqjROPtlkjPpYZvCpKw.text: My friend took me here when I was at the London film festival and it was great to find a place with affordable food that overlooked the Thames (though an even better view is the Pizza Express near the Globe - if you get a window table you have a direct view of St. Paul's and I actually love their pizzas and their doughballs despite the fact they are a chain). And it's right in the middle of the Southbank which is one of my favourite places to be. The staff was OK but get a table by the window and the views will eliminate all thoughts of anything else.

rhls6OeKMPxPBVm8hQKIsA.text: I've not been here for quite a while as it's not the best pizza around but the location makes up for it. Set on the Thames and with an outside seating area it's a great venue for those warm summer evenings, as long as you don't mind eating pretty average pizza.

rkAte3r3l-WlxRCtSdWq3Q.text: Now I'm a bit of a pizza snob, so The Gourmet Pizza Company didn't really do it for me. It was good, no doubt, but I've had much better for quite a bit cheaper. Also, the service is fairly rude. The 2 good things about it have already been stated: It's right off the Thames so you get a wonderful view, and they have a 2 for 1 deal which makes the night quite inexpensive (our pizzas plus a bruschetta and our drinks cost less than £20). It's a nice place to go to once in a while, but as I said, having very set and strict opinions of pizza, I'd say its a little overrated.

88G6Ty7wqavrG33_F5MEhQ.text: Well I have to say after watching my Dad run the London marathon in 4.5 hours I was mighty impressed! A fantastic day was had all, runners and viewers. We chose this place for it's convenient location, nearby the hotel my Dad was staying at. I did think it may be interesting with choices like Beetroot and Duck. The menu looked fine, and the prices were ok. The starters were relatively uninspiring - my mussels in (not) spicy tomato sauce were small and not very tasty. The rest were ok. Then onto the pizza - well I have to say i was shocked - although the toppings were fine, there were stains on the cheese and base - suggesting the sauce and toppings had been in place for sometime - not fresh?!!!! It's pizza - how can you not make it fresh??? The bases on all pizza's were not crispy enough, maybe at the edge, but mainly doughy and extremely hard to cut. Not a good at all. The puddings were ok. The only reason I've given this place a 3 star is for the service - our waitress was great. Pizza should be a  relatively easy thing to produce, good pizza is well worth having. I was severely disappointed Gourment Pizza managed to do such a poor job, especially since my Dad had just run over 26 miles to get there. Meh!!

dAqSU4IOProwqeVelZFbPw.text: I have wandred past this cute little pizza place a few times and always fanciced giving it a try the pizzas looked delicious. I have to say the food didnt disappoint it was very good, and very fresh and served nice and hot.The service was poor however and verged on rude. however you can ignore that if you just want good food in the sunshine and enjoy the views.Make sure you sit outside otherwise you waste everything thats good about this place.

ReuTLqwzkI038uHk4_L9lQ.text: Great place to go if you're down on the south bank. I went to Waterloo last night armed with a load of vouchers for some of the restaurants on the south bank, unfortuately, they were all very very busy and told us we had to wait over a hour to get a table. I was not waiting around, so we walked along the river and stumbled across the Gourmet Pizza Co. Despite not having a voucher for them, they still had a meal deal where you get 2 main meals for the price of 1 which was great! Along with a bottle of wine, our meal came to £21!!! BARGAIN!!! :) The staff were very friendly nad we only had to wait a few minutes till we were seated. The service was very quick and my only gripe is that they brought us the bill before we'd asked for it, as though they were rushing us out.

EcN49MA6-SAyLqjkwAE3Pw.text: Having worked nearby for some years, this has been a regular lunchtime refuge from the office, and it was again today. The beetroot and blue cheese (really) topping hit the spot today - maybe not gourmet but the strong flavours worked well especially with a little chilli oil on the side! If you have hayfever, a good place to go in summer since everyone is outside enjoying the view.

FWrNoL4EgMgSU1c6O5wbfg.text: Had dinner here the other night. We had a great table outside which was perfect for people watching. Three of us shared a bottle of wine and a pizza. The wine was delicious. Was it the best pizza I have ever eaten? No but it was yummy.  They accommodated our request to split toppings on the pie. And the after dinner coffee was decent. The service toward the end of the night could definitely been more attentive though.

G4pGLbf5Ev0js6OsyWogXA.text: Food was amazing here! Risotto was perfect and dessert was divine! We had a chocolate fudge cake which was very moist and chocolatey but not overly rich. We also had an ice cream dessert with praline and caramel. This tasted absolutely gorgeous!The staff were also very kind and attentive, as one waiter even found out the final score of a World Cup match for my boyfriend!As well as this, the restaurant is right on the pier so has a wonderful view! It's also very close to lots of bars and other attractions along the pier.

j1J6u5kBdv4b6--Q_jGRug.text: Zee pizza is perfectly fine. It's a nice place for lunch if you happen to be in the area and want pizza. Not a bad price, plenty of seating, and in a cool little location on Southbank with some fun shops around. Would I come here again if I wanted pizza and I was in the area? Of course, but no need to travel across London for it. Tis A-ok.

photos.caption: Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom. Margherita with extra cheese

JhiotZUlQBJ-ZNtZ8q9zoQ.text: This was our first meal after arriving in London and getting settled in to our flat. Located on the ever-vibrant South Bank it afforded us great views of the waterfront and all the passers-by while we ate. We enjoyed a delicious pasta, bruschetta and beer while being kept nicely warm inside on what felt like a very cold day to us. The staff was quick and cheerful, service was exceptional end to end, and the meal itself was delicious. This was a wonderful welcome to London.

nrMjzCVpnT1lu4zXZSbevA.text: The waiters were amazing and so was the workers, but Half of the menu wasn't available for some reason. I've ordered two pizzas, the Italian and original. Asking for both to be well done. A pro about this was, the service was quick, but a con, well, the pizza wasn't well done. And it was soggy. We've also ordered the Caesar salad, that was a disappointment. The salad was served on a hot plate, causing it to turn soggy. So in conclusion, I will personally never go back there again. But kudos to the workers!

wyxR8WIZ5MmxOZkAUwh3AA.text: This little pizza hut (excuse the pun) has been on Gabriel's Wharf for as long as I can remember.  I always gravitate towards it, take a little walk around the artisan shops around the square, remember that they are all a bit disappointing, then love the quaintness of a permanent pizza fixture in a temporary structure - it literally is a wooden hut, and today we were sat in a tent on the outside of the wooded hut ... still, you can't beat the views and the excitement of finding an independent eatery in an area that is becoming increasingly corporate.What a shame that Gourmet Pizza don't take more pride in their food and try to live up to their name.  Every time I go I forget why I was disappointed the last time.  Time to write a little review to remind myself - this is fast food rather than gourmet with maximum numbers of people crammed into a small space, orders taken and delivered in record time (probably a good thing if you are fitting in a pre-theatre meal, I give you that ...); the pizza base is tasty but nothing special and not even crusty, the toppings not fresh: the peppers and caramelised onions on my veggie pizza today were definitely from a tin, presumably so were the bits of aubergine and courgette (cut up too small to get a proper taste).  The overall result was OK, but only just.The location is great and they probably have great passing trade, what a shame they don't care enough to make this a more enjoyable experience to make people return more frequently.

photos.caption: Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom

lTKl7vPTE36SNsJZWuYrjQ.text: Delicious food, consistent service, really give this place a try you will not be left disappointed, I have had the Tropean pizza for an entree two days in a row and I'm not a pizza fan but I love it with the chili oil yummy! My sister ordered the Frutti di Mare pasta she said it was delicious as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom. Tropean pizza with the Frutti di Mare pasta
Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom. Caprese Salad

1tUpZu0ACLlrRRCyg9DwoA.text: Fantastic location right by the river, especially when it's warm and you can sit outside and pretend you're on holiday. As mentioned by others, it is cramped so probably best avoided if you prefer quiet, spacious dining. Get the chorizo and pumpkin ravioli. I had it as a starter but it also comes as a main. Glistening with butter, it was the standout dish for me. I found my large salad supremely healthy if a little lacking in execution. Not enough avocado and too much raw rocket made it particularly peppery. Honeycomb cheesecake sounded better than it was. (I feel like I'm often disappointed by restaurant cheesecakes.)Still, service was speedy and amicable. Plus, with a taste card, the meal was unbelievably good value - £13.50 for three courses.

photos.caption: Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom. Honeycomb cheesecake
Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom. The first salad listed, goat's cheese, avocado and tings

HGMzVZ47tuRTiA8NDejr3w.text: I don't know what it is but we seem to have had a lot of pizza on our London trip.  That said, the food here good.  I don't know that I would call it Gourmet.  It's been the best pizza of our trip though.  The service here was very good.   It's on the south bank walkway, for for a touristy type place, not a bad choice.

bR46B4Lz96SKVdGa2UCK0w.text: We came across this amazingly located restaurant after a full day of sightseeing here in London. It is located right on the Thames River and a great spot to catch a sunset.We were all exhausted but looking for a tasty meal to end our day with.  Since we arrived late in the night when they were going to close, we ended up sitting inside. The restaurant is not by any means large, so everyone is pretty close together, in fact when the woman next to me was putting her coat on, I got whacked in the head.....We ordered a pizza, lasagna and garlic bread. We were all looking forward to our meal. It did take a while to receive and most of the staff seemed to all be little confused about who was covering the various tables. When dinner finally arrived, the pizza was thin crust and just ok. The lasagna was a huge disappointment. It was served in a skillet pan and it was just basically noodles, sauce and cheese. It almost looked like a crepe with sauce on top. I have never tasted lasagna like this and I was not too thrilled. Maybe I missed the boat and ordered the wrong item???Does this place live up to its name Gourmet Pizza?? Not really. Would I return again, probably not. I would think in a location like this, the service would have been top notch as this is a very busy section of the city.

RHoHyUO-RcqWRC1pqMwymg.text: The first thing to notice about this place is obviously the location. You get a beautiful view over the river and that's always delightful! However, the prime location comes at a cost, mostly in the form of very little wiggle room. The tables are incredibly close together and both my friend and myself struggled to find space for our rucksacks, there was also the annoyance of the two tables around ours being so close that we constantly bumped into other people's chairs or were pushed by people standing up or sitting down. Trying to get to the loo without plowing through people was an adventure!We both had a pasta dish, so I can't comment on the actual pizza, but the pesto pasta was okay! Good flavour and a nice large helping of extra cheese were plus points, a big puddle of oil being left in the bottom of the plate was a big minus point. Our server was quite rushed, effective but not courteous or friendly. It seemed very much like they just want to get you in and out as fast as possible.

kipxo8VwSvjXVHzKrOeOLA.text: Great restaurant by the Southbank riverwalk and it's very close to Mondrian Hotel! The pasta serving was pretty generous. Pizza is a thin-crusted pizza with great topping options! It gets crowded for dinner and can be a bit cramped but when you get the seats outside, enjoy the view!

photos.caption: Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom

Ttp0FRNLnoAJRe2Kd0xegw.text: We walked here our first day in London, and came across this restaurant. Hungry for pizza, we came here to eat. The service was good, nothing extremely out of the ordinary. We ordered the dough balls, a tuna pasta, and a margherita pizza for us (3 people) to share. Unlike the name suggests, the pizza was mediocre. It was something you could expect at a fast food pizza place. The dough balls were amazing. The garlic butter isn't too overwhelming, and it didn't have pieces of garlic in it. They tasted good with or without the garlic butter. The tuna pasta was pretty good, but it was spicy, so I decided to order a lasagna, which I noticed earlier. That was the best decision. When the lasagna arrived, I knew it would be good. It was sizzling, and the layer of cheese on top was melted and yummy. It tasted so good, that's all I can say. Perfect. Come here, definitely, but don't order the pizza, get a pasta instead.

wBvmYvjwt2dCbdnHElr09w.text: We stumbled upon Gourmet Pizza Co. on the first full day of a recent European vacation, and we (two adults and two teens) were not disappointed in the least, despite our jaded American pickiness over pizza and like fare.  Be prepared for a loud, busy venue (the words "sonic cacophony" come to mind) but the food was very good and the value was excellent in comparison to other options in touristy parts of the London south bank. The location is very nice and the staff is friendly, quick and competent.Two of us had pizzas, one had a salad and one had an Italian entree.  Everyone was happy and our bank of British pounds remained relatively unbroken.  Gourmet Pizza is a winner, and a good choice for families with kids and teens. Pizza fundamentally does not rate five starts.  If it did, this venue would earn them.

qGyEgkR4_eYZh-W0a9YAzQ.text: I hate to admit it but I'm quite a big fan of Pizza Express (who didn't love it though?!). However, I really loved trying the Gourmet Pizza place and would definitely recommend it. Such a lovely location on the river in Gabriel's Wharf and the staff are lovely.There's a great range of pizzas and they're all freshly made to order, which I love. I ordered the cajun chicken, bacon and goats cheese pizza but asked for it without the peppers. There were four of us and I think we all removed our substituted something on our pizzas but it wasn't a problem for them at all. The pizzas were all really good with plenty of toppings and they were very tasty. The only thing was that we all struggled to cut through the bases. They were thin and crispy and obviously hand made (just how I like them) but these were perhaps a little too crispy. Even if they gave us pizza cutters or sharper knives we wouldn't have minded so much as they didn't taste bad and they weren't burnt.It is a little on the pricey side for what you get but we had a voucher which made it really good value.I'll definitely visit again, especially in the summer with the wonderful location and view, and I'd recommend giving it a try to anyone thinking of going to a nearby Pizza Express!

RMjLjwV9CnAGrDs824ZKxQ.text: Stopped in here on a Saturday evening for a quick dinner with friends. No reservation, and apparently after a 10 minute wait, no problem! We were sat at a long table and as we were provided with menus while waiting, we all knew what to order. It looks like everybody at the table ordered something different and they all looked good. I went for a slightly different pizza to normal, bacon (normal) with beets (not normal) and blue cheese (even more not normal). The combination however totally works. Bit of banter with the staff and we all had a good time for surprisingly good money seeing as we were on the South Bank. Sceptical going in and very happy to be proven wrong.

JDo9TJMPxyU3071FLB6yvA.text: I'm finding it increasingly hard to get excited about pizza restaurants these days and this experience was no exception.The menu was very limited, most options are vegetarian with only two 'meaty' options (one being prosciutto and rocket), not so good if you like your home comforts.I quite like trying new things when out and it's hard to get enthusiastic as there just seemed to be a lack a variety here. There were a lot of options you don't normally find on run of the mill pizza restaurants, however these all seemed very traditional and nothing stood out as being novel.Opting for the Hot & Spicy Macho, I found this to be an average pizza with a thick topping of meat and cheese, the base being a little soggy for my liking as I've always been more excited about the crispy bases.The chicken and goats cheese salad we shared was impressive in size. You get a lot of bang for your buck with a lot of salad and selection of leaves, chicken and cheese, but whilst I was impressed with this, it was drenched in salad dressing, so unless you specify at the time of ordering, don't expect a healthy alternative here!The most outstanding part of this experience was the location, based right on the river this is indeed a romantic spot, I could assume when it's raining that it would be lovely to spend a romantic afternoon here over shared pizza and drinks.The prices aren't cheap, however you are paying for location, however you need to get to the front of the restaurant for the views.The staff were a little icy, but it was quite late be honest.I couldn't but help leaving a little devoid of enthusiasm for this place, I was expecting something a little more exceptional from a restaurant named 'Gourmet'.

JMKMqAGy2DUYc0D4bJwIbw.text: The location...trendy and romantic.  The food...average.  The service...meh.  That is the quick and dirty.  Originally I was wanting some seafood, but after seeing the menus for the other restaurants nearby, pizza was staring so sound really good.  We ducked in and had to dodge prams sitting in the doorway.  There just is not enough space in the restaurant.  We were considering sitting outside, but that was not offered as an option.  We ended up sitting in the balcony area that is enclosed.  Note:  if you are on a date with the Incredible Hulk...or just your average 6'2" man, it will be a bit cramped.  As Jeremy Clarkson said, "This will involve man touching."  While the wait staff seemed to be very friendly with each other, they weren't nearly as friendly with us.  We ordered the dough balls to start with.  If you are quite hungry, you will want two orders as the dough balls are quite small. Mr. Snarky had the Spicy Chorizo Pizza while I ordered the Fiorentina.  The Spicy Chorizo had some red peppers as well as onion.  The Fiorentina had spinach, and egg.  While I appreciated the fact that the crust on my pizza was not burnt, like a lot of places that do the thin crust pizza, I was a bit sad that the yolk on the egg was solid, not runny.  I think that would have enhanced the pizza.  I also enjoyed the spicy olive oil on the table so I could dip my crust in it...or drizzle it all over.  It wasn't bad and I would probably come back again if I were in the area and craving pizza.

HFVIhS6Q1t7PWnVJ190DRQ.text: Came here for a catch up dinner with a friend I haven't seen for months.It's a brilliant location, just along Southbank, we were seated outside, so had a great view of the river (well my friend had her back to it so I did but...) and a great people watching spot. It is a little crowded in there and we were quite squished in to our table for 2, definitely not the place if you want a discreet intimate dinner, considering the proximity to other tables. We shared some garlic dough balls to start, they were good, nothing really amazing, the pizza I had though was delicious, I loved the more interesting options available especially as a veggie I had the Vedure di Capra, the base was crispy and the toppings were plenty exactly how I like it. We shared a bottle of the house red and sadly we didn't have time for dessert. We came on a tastecard so it was super cheap for us, but overall the prices are really good considering the location. The service was friendly and efficient.Lovely place for a quick dinner in a great location, not so good for an intimate meal.

EH5roBiacAFmO7209Ov34A.text: If you are looking for a nice place for team lunch around Southbank you should check this one out. The pizza is delicious and you get a great view of the river and the building in the area. While not many people know about the food around Gabriel's Wharf, everyone who has been there has told me how good it is and ever since I went there myself it is one of my top places to pick when I want some good pizza at a reasonable price (and a glass of red please).

photos.caption: Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Gourmet Pizza Co - London, United Kingdom
